Related publications are listed in the metadata section of the Dataverse study.

fields.value: Replication Data for: Consumer demand heterogeneity and valuation of value added pulse products: a case of precooked beans in Uganda

authorAffiliation.value: Department of Agricultural Economics, Kansas State University
International Center for Tropical Agriculture - CIAT
International Center for Tropical Agriculture - CIAT
International Center for Tropical Agriculture - CIAT
National Semi Arid Resources Research Institute

datasetContactAffiliation.value: International Center for Tropical Agriculture - CIAT

dsDescriptionValue.value:
The data is from a survey conducted in Central Uganda in August 2015 by the National Crops Resources Research Institute in collaboration with CIAT-PABRA. This study investigated consumer demand heterogeneity and valuation of a processed bean product— “precooked beans” with substantially reduced cooking time. The study aimed at segmenting potential consumers of precooked beans and to determine their willingness to pay for the same when introduced on the market. 
Data file consists of variables on: i) consumer choices/preferences collected using a choice experiment, ii) social and demographics, iii) bean consumption dynamics, bean preparation methods, perceptions of food processing and market access.

publicationCitation.value:
Aseete et al. Agric & Food Secur (2018) 7:51 
https://doi.org/10.1186/s40066-018-0203-3       
(Paul Aseete, Enid Katungi, Jackline Bonabana‑Wabbi, Eliud Birachi and Michael Adrogu Ugen. Consumer demand heterogeneity and valuation of value‑added pulse products: A case of precooked beans in Uganda.

grantNumberAgency.value: The Cultivate Africa‘s Future (CultiAF by IDRC and ACIAR)
Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research (ACIAR)

value: Data were collected from 558 households from urban, peri-urban and rural parts of central Uganda in the districts of Kampala, Mukono, Wakiso, Buikwe, and Luwero. These were selected because of their high population density and levels of urbanization, high cost of energy for cooking and the importance of common bean in household diets. They thus make up the most probable market for the precooked bean. The information was collected at household level with the principle decision maker in a household, either the household head or spouse responding to the full survey. In cases where the household head was absent the spouse was interviewed.
